Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Provide guidance to clients regarding machine usage
Situation2: An operator keeps tweaking settings incorrectly, causing noticeable material waste.
Story:
I stared at my phone, the group chat buzzing with messages from my stepbrother. “Don’t forget, you promised to help set up for the holiday dinner tonight!” he wrote, followed by a string of festive emojis. My stepmom chimed in, reminding me how important it was for the whole family to be together, especially since I’d missed the last gathering. I could almost hear the disappointment in her words, the unspoken hope that I’d finally fit in.

But at the same time, my work phone vibrated. The operator at the factory was calling again—third time today. He kept adjusting the machine settings, ignoring my previous instructions, and now the material waste was piling up. My supervisor expected me to guide him, to prevent further losses, and to be available for urgent troubleshooting. I felt the pressure mounting from both sides: the warmth and expectation of family, the responsibility and urgency of my job. My stomach twisted as I realized I couldn’t be in two places at once, and both sides needed me right now.
